content.title: Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) for Varicose Veins
content.definition: Minimally invasive endovenous thermal ablation technique using radiofrequency energy to heat and destroy the vein wall, causing fibrosis and eventual occlusion of incompetent saphenous veins. Also known as ClosureFast or VNUS Closure.

key_concepts.description: Radiofrequency energy heats catheter tip to 120°C causing thermal denaturation of collagen in vein wall → immediate vein contraction → fibrosis → occlusion. Temperature-controlled and segmental.
Symptomatic great saphenous vein (GSV) or small saphenous vein (SSV) reflux; CEAP C2-C6 disease; typically for veins 3-12mm diameter; straight vein course
Acute superficial or deep vein thrombosis; known hypercoagulable state with current clot; pregnancy; very tortuous veins; previous thrombophlebitis of target vein

Dilute local anesthetic (0.1% lidocaine with epinephrine in saline) injected around vein under ultrasound guidance; provides anesthesia, compresses vein for wall contact, and protects surrounding tissue from thermal injury
Ultrasound-guided access below knee; catheter advanced to saphenofemoral or saphenopopliteal junction; positioned 2cm from junction; tumescent infiltration; pullback with 20-second heating cycles
Catheter tip placed 2cm from saphenofemoral junction (SFJ) to avoid injury to femoral vein; first treatment zone may receive double treatment for secure closure
Occlusion rates >95% at 5 years; equivalent or superior to stripping; faster recovery than surgery; less pain and bruising than laser ablation
RFA: segmental, temperature-controlled, less painful; EVLT: continuous, energy-controlled, more bruising/pain. Both have similar long-term efficacy.
Bruising, pain (less than EVLT); paresthesia (saphenous nerve injury); DVT/extension into deep vein (rare, <1%); skin burns (rare with proper tumescent); phlebitis
Compression stockings for 1-2 weeks; walking encouraged immediately; duplex ultrasound at 1-2 weeks to confirm occlusion and exclude DVT; sclerotherapy for residual varicosities

learning_objectives: Understand the mechanism of radiofrequency thermal ablation
Recognize the importance of tumescent anesthesia
Know key differences between RFA and laser ablation
clinical_pearls: Position catheter 2cm from SFJ to protect femoral vein
Less painful than laser ablation due to temperature control
Occlusion rates >95% at 5 years - excellent durability
Can walk immediately - outpatient office-based procedure
Follow-up duplex at 1-2 weeks to confirm closure and rule out DVT
common_mistakes: Placing catheter too close to saphenofemoral junction
Inadequate tumescent anesthesia (risk of burns, pain)
Treating tortuous segments not amenable to catheter advancement
Not confirming vein compression with ultrasound before ablation
